I think you failed to grasp what David was saying.  Evolution is not a
lear=
ning algorithm in the traditional sense.  However, it is how the
topography=
 of the brain was created in the first place.  If you're looking
simply for=
 learning algorithms I suggest you look into any of a great number
of resou=
rces available for training neural networks.  As David pointed out,
much of=
 the work to date represents a radical simplification of biological
systems=
.  If you're looking for something that closely mimics biology you
might lo=
ok at work that has been done in modeling a single neuron.  That's
probably=
 almost as good as it gets for the time being.

- Jeff


On Sun, Nov 29, 20=
09 at 1:26 AM, Richard Gong <gongrichard@...> wrote:

>
>
> Evolution=
 is not how biological neural networks learn. Are there any
> projects (sim=
ilar in scope/usability to NEAT) that are more faithful to
> biology?
>
> R=
ichard Gong
>
>
> ---------- Forwarded message ----------
> From: Dave Tour=
etzky <dst@...>
> Date: Sat, Nov 28, 2009 at 1:59 AM
> S=
ubject: Re: AI
> To: Richard Gong <richardgong@...>
>
>
> > Are there=
 any coding projects similar to NEAT, in its generalized
> > ability, but m=
ore like the brain's "live" learning?
>
> No one knows in detail how learni=
ng works in the brain.  We don't know
> how most things are represented, or=
 how those representations get
> updated.  All we have right now are highly=
 simplified models at various
> levels of abstraction, but we know that the=
se are inadequate.
>
> Don't be misled by computer scientists who give simp=
le learning
> mechanisms fancy biological names, like "neural network" or "=
genetic
> algorithm".  These are highly simplified and abstract mathematica=
l
> constructs compared to the complicated and messy biological phenomena
>=
 they are named after.  It's like the difference between the hypothetical
>=
 canonball's simple 1D trajectory in a vacuum, vs. a real world
> knuckleba=
ll whose spin and trajectory can only be explained using vector
> calculus =
and fluid dynamics.
>
> So to answer your original question: no, we don't h=
ave a general purpose
> learning rule that works like the brain, because we=
 don't understand how
> the brain works.
>
> And although brains have very =
powerful learning algorithms, they also
> have a lot of built-in structure =
that is present from birth.  Most
> machine learning algorithms start out w=
ith zero weights, or initial
> random weights, not the incredibly detailed =
structure produced by our
> genes through the process of fetal development.=
  So don't think that
> some simple learning algorithm is going to provide =
the "magic bullet"
> that produces intelligent machines.  It's not going to=
 be that easy.  It
> took evolution a long time to come up with the structu=
re of the
> mammalian brain.  And it's going to take us another century or =
two to
> figure out how it works.
>
> -- Dr. David S. Touretzky
>   Researc=
h Professor
>   Computer Science Department &
>     Center for the Neural B=
asis of Cognition
>   Carnegie Mellon University
>   Pittsburgh, PA 15213-3=
891
>   tel. 412-268-7561
>
>  
>



-- 
...imagine a puddle waking up one =
morning and thinking, 'This is an
interesting world I find myself in, an in=
teresting hole I find myself in,
fits me rather neatly, doesn't it? In fact=
 it fits me staggeringly well,
must have been made to have me in it!' This =
is such a powerful idea that as
the sun rises in the sky and the air heats =
up and as, gradually, the puddle
gets smaller and smaller, it's still frant=
ically hanging on to the notion
that everything's going to be alright, beca=
use this world was meant to have
him in it, was built to have him in it; so=
 the moment he disappears catches
him rather by surprise. I think this may =
be something we need to be on the
watch out for.

-- Douglas Adams

--0016e652f6b0126d6004797d2f8b

arning algorithm in the traditional sense. =A0However, it is how the topogr=
aphy of the brain was created in the first place. =A0If you're looking =
simply for learning algorithms I suggest you look into any of a great numbe=
r of resources available for training neural networks. =A0As David pointed =
out, much of the work to date represents a radical simplification of biolog=
ical systems. =A0If you're looking for something that closely mimics bi=
ology you might look at work that has been done in modeling a single neuron=
. =A0That's probably almost as good as it gets for the time being.<div>=
